{{sidebar | title = Roman Funerary Art | image = [[File:Tombstone of Nertus.jpg|250px]] | caption = Tombstone of the cavalry veteran Nertus, son of Dumnotalis | contentclass = hlist | headingclass = navbox-abovebelow | headingstyle = font-size:105%; | heading1 = Funerary Practices | content1 = *[[Roman funerary practices]] *[[Funerary art]] *[[mausolea]] *[[altars]] *[[sarcophagi]] *[[catacombs]] *[[tombstones]] }} '''Roman funerary art''' changed throughout the course of the Republic and the Empire and comprised many different forms. There were two main burial practices used by the Romans throughout history, one being cremation, another inhumation. The vessels that resulted from these practices include sarcophagi, ash chests, urns, and altars. In addition to these, buildings such as [[mausoleum]]s, [[stela]]e, and other monuments were also popular forms used to commemorate the dead. The method by which Romans were memorialized was determined by social class, religion, and other factors. While monuments to the dead were constructed within Roman cities, the remains themselves were interred outside the cities.
After the end of [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]] rule, Roman lawmakers became very strict regarding the ethics of laying the dead to rest. A prime issue was the legality and morality of interring the dead within the city limits. It was nearly unanimous at first to move the dead outside of the [[pomerium]] to ensure the separation of their souls from the living, and many politicians remained assertive in enforcing the idea well into the Empire.<ref name="Patterson_265">{{harvp|Patterson|2000|p=265}}</ref> [[Cicero]] reminds his readers of the [[Law of the Twelve Tables]]: "A dead man shall not be buried or burned inside the city" ([[De Legibus]], 2, 23:58). Three centuries later, [[Julius Paulus Prudentissimus|Paulus]] writes in his [[Julius Paulus Prudentissimus#Paulus's legal works|Sententiae]], "You are not allowed to bring a corpse into the city in case the sacred places in the city are polluted. Whoever acts against these restrictions is punished with unusual severity. You are not allowed to cremate a body within the walls of the city" (1, 21:2-3). Many Roman towns and [[Roman province|provinces]] had similar rules, often in their charters, such as the [[Lex Ursonensis]].<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2007|p=130}}</ref> Particularly at the very end of the Republic, exceptions to this principle became more frequent, albeit only for the most powerful leaders. The means used to commemorate the dead served to acknowledge the gods, but also served as means of social expression depicting Roman values and history.
[[Early Christians]] continued this custom until [[Late Antiquity]], but liked to be buried close to the graves of [[martyr]]s; the catacombs and great churches that grew up around the fringes of Rome were then outside the walls.
==Mausolea== ''See [[mausoleum]].''
===Etymology=== The mausoleum is so named for [[Mausolus]] of [[Caria]] (377-353/2 BC), a ruler in what is now [[Turkey]]. He was a profound patron of [[Hellenistic culture]]. After, or perhaps before his death, his wife and sister [[Artemisia II of Caria|Artemisia]] commissioned the [[Mausoleum at Halicarnassus]] as an enormous tomb for him above ground; it was one of the [[Seven Wonders of the ancient world]], and much of the sculpture is now in Berlin. Such had been a trend in [[Ancient Greece|Greece]] during the centuries before Mausolus, as it was a means of further solidifying the memory of the prominent deceased. At the time, the ancient Mediterranean world was in the midst of a [[Hellenistic period|revival of Greek ideologies]], present in politics, religion, the arts, and social life. The [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] were no exception to this trend.<ref>{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=30}}</ref>
===Occupants=== Mausolea generally had multiple occupants because their space was so vast, although this notion took time to become commonplace in the [[Roman Republic#Early Republic (458–274 BC)|early Republic]], as did the idea of "[[Burial|burying]]" the dead above ground. [[Mass grave|Mass burials]] were common, but only for the common folk. Royalty, politicians, [[List of Roman generals|generals]], and the richest citizens originally shared a tomb with no more than their immediate family. Changes were gradual largely because [[Roman funerary practices|funerary practices]] tended to follow strict traditions, especially in the ancient world.<ref name="Colvin_16">{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=16}}</ref> It took centuries to conceive the "Roman" concept of the mausoleum. Meanwhile, the idea of lavish decoration of burial sites remained present throughout the [[Roman Republic|Republic]] and the [[Roman Empire|Empire]]. In context, above ground structures of the Empire and [[Roman Republic#Late Republic (147–30 BC)|Late Republic]] contained art suitable to the lives of the occupants the same way their underground alternatives did.
===Locations=== Few mausolea inside the Pomerium predated the empire. Most mausolea existed on designated burial grounds in the country, though city exemptions to the prohibition of mortuary buildings only increased during the Empire. It was also popular to build them along main roads so that they would be consistently visible to the public. A trend of the [[History of the Roman Empire|Middle and Late Empire]] was to build mausolea on family property, even if it was within the city limits.<ref name="Patterson_265"/>
===History===
====''Pre-Republic''==== The Romans absorbed a great deal of [[Funerary art#Etruscans|Etruscan funerary art]] practices. Above ground mausolea were still rare; underground tombs and [[Tumulus|tumuli]] were far more common methods of burial. The [[Roman Kingdom|early Romans]] buried those who could not afford such accommodations in [[mass grave]]s or [[Cremation|cremated]] them.<ref name="Patterson_265"/> Of the few mausolea that they did build during Rome's infancy, many fell to [[ruins]] under unknown circumstances. Their absence thus renders little indication of the Romans' mausoleum practices during these years. A notable exception is in Praeneste, or present day [[Palestrina]], where approximately forty early mausolea remain.<ref>{{harvp|Smith|2000|p=23}}</ref>
====''Early Republic''==== Etruscan influence remained, and there became more consistency in the styles of mausolea as Roman influence increased throughout the [[Latin League]]. Structures from this era are rare, but as with the preceding centuries, most of those that the Romans built at this time no longer exist.<ref name="Patterson_265"/>
====''Mid Republic''==== Rome, along with the rest of the Mediterranean world, experienced a resurgence of [[Ancient Greece#Culture|Greek culture]], known as the [[Hellenistic period]].<ref name="Patterson_265"/> Both the interiors and exteriors of mausolea adopted staples of [[Classical architecture]] such as [[barrel vault]]ed roofs; [[klinai]], which were full body benches upon which the dead lay; painted [[facade]]s; ornate [[Column#Classical orders|columns]]; and [[frieze]]s along the roofs. During this era, most Romans acknowledged the idea that above ground burial allows the public to better remember the deceased.<ref name="Colvin_16"/> Clearly in accordance with their embraces of tradition and [[Virtue#Roman Virtues|virtues]] of the [[mos maiorum]], Romans began to set aside money to build vast new mausolea for the preservation of their legacies.<ref>{{harvp|Patterson|2000|p=273}}</ref> Of course, this trend was gradual, but had gained ground by the [[Crisis of the Roman Republic|end of the Republic]].
The [[Tomb of the Scipios]] is an example of a large underground rock-cut set of chambers used by the [[Scipio (cognomen)|Scipio]] family from the 3rd to the 1st centuries BC. It was grand, but relatively inconspicuous above ground.
Also present was an influence from the [[Anatolia|lands east of Greece]]. Although the architectural contributions of [[Asia Minor]] were very different from those of the Greeks, Asia Minor had previously opened itself to Hellenic styles earlier in the fourth century BC. The Romans borrowed most of their architecture during these years from the Greeks, so most of the Roman styles similar to those of Asia Minor actually came to Rome via Greece. Of course, the Romans borrowed directly from the Greek style as well. Anatolian mausolea are distinct via their tower designs, a notable example being the [[Harpy Tomb]], built circa 480-470 BC.<ref name="Colvin_21">{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=21}}</ref>
Nearing the [[Roman Republic#Late Republic (147–30 BC)|Late Republic]], the new diversity in design allowed those who could afford it to build larger and more lavish mausolea. Although politicians, particularly [[Roman Senate|senators]], had always used their monuments to proclaim their status, they increasingly saw the grandeur of their mausolea as an additional outlet of expressing political dominance.<ref name="Patterson_265"/> Around this time, most Romans had accepted the similarities of mausolea and [[Roman temple|temples]], although their ancestors had been conscious of this apparent analogue for centuries.<ref name="Colvin_21"/>
====''Late Republic''==== Within the final two centuries of the Republic, Roman mausolea acquired inspiration from another geographical region: [[History of Africa#Roman North Africa|North Africa]]. North African architecture itself had succumbed to Greek practices since Greco-[[Phoenicia]]n [[Phoenicia#Trade|trade settlements]] since the eighth century BC. Again, the Romans embraced the style as they solidified their conquest of North Africa in the second and first centuries BC. By the time of [[Augustus]], the influences of Greece, Asia Minor, and Africa combined to make a unique [[Ancient Roman architecture|"Roman" style]].<ref>{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=29}}</ref>
As the Republic ended, more people continued to forgo the rules against city burials.<ref name="Patterson_266">{{harvp|Patterson|2000|p=266}}</ref> One of the last Republican leaders to do so was [[Sulla]], who opted to build a mausoleum on the [[Campus Martius]].<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2007|p=137}}</ref> Many burial grounds outside of the city became crowded because mausolea had not but increased in size, ornateness, and quantity since the Hellenistic Era. In the first century BC, some Romans settled for smaller and simpler mausolea in order to just reserve space on a prominent burial ground, such as the [[Isola Sacra Necropolis]] outside of [[Portus]], where visitors can notice the smaller mausolea desperately filling random space around the more properly distanced larger ones.<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2007|p=134}}</ref> [[Howard Colvin]] cites the mausolea of the [[Roman consul|consul]] [[List of Roman consuls#1st century AD|Minicius Fundanus]] on [[Monte Mario]] and the [[Licinia (gens)|Licinii]]-[[Calpurnia (gens)|Calpurnii]] on [[Via Salaria]] as examples of more compact structures that came to scatter burial sites.<ref name="Patterson_266"/>
The [[Tomb of Eurysaces the Baker]] (50-20 BC) is a flamboyant example of a rich [[freedman]]'s tomb, with reliefs exemplifying an Italic style less influenced by Hellenistic art than official or patrician monuments.
====''Early Empire''==== [[File:SPLIT-Mausoleum 1912.jpg|thumb|Plan of [[Split Cathedral]], built as the mausoleum of [[Diocletian]] in [[Split, Croatia]]]] The [[Roman Empire#Government and military|new government]] of Rome brought a new approach to mausolea politically and socially. The non-elite became ever present in the senate, putting a damper on many of the longtime rivalries of the [[Roman aristocracy|aristocracy]]. Because they many of these men were [[Novus homo|homines novi]], or new men, they had other incentives to assert dominance; Patterson observes that their mausolea focused more upon giving prestige to their own name rather than toppling that of someone else. Such an agenda is discernable through the increased interest of building mausolea on family property.<ref name="Patterson_267">{{harvp|Patterson|2000|p=267}}</ref> Many wealthy families owned magnificent estates in the country, where they were free from the burial laws of the city. While the art and design of the structures themselves remained grandiose, builders shifted interest to decorating the land around the mausoleum. Statues, podia, [[stele]]s, and horti (gardens), gained popularity amongst those who had the space and money to erect mausolea on their own property.<ref>{{harvp|Patterson|2000|p=271}}</ref> The [[Pyramid of Cestius]] of about 12 BC remains a rather eccentric Roman landmark; he had perhaps served in [[Nubia]]n campaigns.
With the advent of the Empire came an extreme augmentation in the inclusivity of mausolea on two ways. First, the occupation of many new mausolea was greater than that of their Republican predecessors, which generally reserved space for nobody other than their immediate family. Many in the Empire who commissioned mausolea in their name also requested room for extended family, [[Slavery in ancient Rome|slaves]], [[Slavery in ancient Rome#Freedmen|freedmen]], [[concubine]]s, [[Patronage in ancient Rome|clients]], animals, and other intimate acquaintances.<ref name="Patterson_266"/> Second, more people who could normally not afford a mausoleum were able to acquire one. Aside from those a master invited to his mausoleum, certain freedmen received their own mausoleum with financial assistance from their former masters. Some of the freedmen's mausolea are equally as impressive as those of wealthy citizens.<ref>{{harvp|Patterson|2000|p=269}}</ref>
====''Late Empire''==== No later than the end of the second century AD did Rome reach its territorial apex as an empire. The initially slow, but quickly hastening [[Decline of the Roman Empire|decline of the Empire]] allowed the mausoleum to fall into the hands of Roman constituents and [[Barbarian|enemies]]. Notably, after the [[Third Century Crisis]], the revival of the mausoleum during the [[tetrarchy]] and beyond spawned interest amongst the [[Religion in ancient Rome#Christianity in the Roman Empire|Christian population]]. They began to build mausolea in the same edificial style as the Romans had for the duration of the empire, and decorated them with [[Christian art]]work. Mausolea continued to be a prime means of interring multiple individuals in the [[Middle Ages]].<ref name="Colvin_53">{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=53}}</ref>
The [[Mausoleum of Helena]] in Rome, built by [[Constantine I]] for himself, but later used for his mother, remains a traditional form, but the church of [[Santa Costanza]] there, built as a mausoleum for Constantine's daughter, was built over an important catacomb where [[Saint Agnes]] was buried, and either was always intended, or soon developed as, a [[funerary hall]] where burial spots could be bought by Christians. Most of the great Christian [[basilica]]s in Rome passed through a stage as funerary halls, full of sarcophagi and slab memorials, before being turned into more conventional churches in the [[Early Middle Ages]].
===Notable Mausolea of Emperors===
====Augustus==== {{main|Mausoleum of Augustus}} [[File:Roma-mausoleo di augusto.jpg|thumb|Front facade of the Mausoleum of Augustus]] [[Augustus]] did the unspeakable in 28 BC and erected a mausoleum on the [[Campus Martius]], a previously public land upon which infrastructure was normally illegal. This challenged his claim to be [[Princeps]], as his enemies found such an action to be too ambitious for a regular [[Roman citizenship|citizen]] and thus above the law. Notable features of the mausoleum included a bronze statue of Augustus, [[pyre]]s, and [[Obelisk#Egyptian|Egyptian obelisks]] among the various usual mortuary ornaments. The mausoleum suffered severe destruction in 410 AD during the [[Sack of Rome (410)|Gothic invasion]] of Rome in 410 AD.<ref>{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=43}}</ref>
====Hadrian==== {{main|Mausoleum of Hadrian}} [[File:Castel Sant Angelo Roma Italy 2013 03 a.jpg|thumb| [[Castel Sant'Angelo]], the Mausoleum of Hadrian; the [[Aelian Bridge]] is on the right, leading directly to the Pons Aelius, also the work of Hadrian.]] [[Hadrian]] had a grand mausoleum, now better known as the [[Castel Sant'Angelo]], for himself and his family in the [[Pons Aelius]] in 120 AD. In addition to its fame as the resting spot of the emperor, the construction of the mausoleum is famous in its own right, as it has a particularly complex vertical design. A rectangular base supports the usual cylindrical frame. Atop the frame is a garden roof with a [[baroque]] monument bearing the statue of an angel.<ref>{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=49}}</ref> The original statue, that of a golden [[quadriga]], among other treasures fell victim to various attacks when the mausoleum served as a castle and a papal fortress during the [[Middle Ages]]. Over a century would pass before a new mausoleum would house the remains of an emperor. The corruption of the [[Severan dynasty|Severans]] and the [[Third Century Crisis]] did not permit very much opportunity for such a glorious memorialization.<ref>{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=50}}</ref>
====The Tetrarchy==== {{main|Tetrarchy}} [[Diocletian]], [[Maxentius]], [[Galerius]], and [[Constantius I]] all had their own mausolea.<ref name="Colvin_52">{{harvp|Colvin|1991|p=52}}</ref> Diocletian and Galerius, who ruled the [[Eastern Empire]], have particularly visible eastern influences in their mausolea, now both churches.<ref name="Colvin_53"/> Viewers can observe the tower in the former's building, built on [[Diocletian's Palace]] in [[Split, Croatia]] and the dark oil murals on the interior of the latter's, in [[Thessalonica]]. Diocletian's mausoleum is now the main part of [[Cathedral of Saint Domnius|Split Cathedral]]. The [[Mausoleum of Maxentius]] outside Rome is the only one of the four in Italy. It lies on the [[Via Appia]], where his [[villa]] and [[Circus (building)|circus]] lie in ruins. Colvin asserts that the army likely buried Constantius in [[Trier]], but there is no material evidence.<ref name="Colvin_52"/>
==Funerary altars== [[File:Togatus Barberini 2392.PNG|thumb|upright|The so-called ''[[Togatus Barberini]]'' in the [[Capitoline Museums]] may represent a senator holding two ancestral funerary portraits ''([[Roman funerary practices#Imagines|imagines]])'']] In ancient Rome, Roman citizens would memorialize their dead by creating cippi or grave altars. These altars became, not just commissioned by the rich, but also commonly erected by freedmen and slaves.<ref>{{harvp|Hornblower|Spawforth|Eidinow|2012|p=87}}</ref> The function of these altars was either to house the ashes of the dead or just to symbolically commemorate the memory of the deceased.<ref name="Toynbee_266">{{harvp|Toynbee|1996|p=266}}</ref> Often, practical funerary altars were constructed to display vessels that contained the ashes and burnt bones of the deceased. These ash urns were placed in deep cavities of the altars that were then covered with a lid.<ref name="Kleiner_22">{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=22}}</ref> Other times, there was a depression in the altar in which libations could be poured.<ref>{{harvp|Toynbee|1996|p=253}}</ref> Some Roman funerary altars were provided with pipes so that these libations could "nourish" the remains.<ref name="Kleiner_22"/> Less commonly, the body of the deceased was placed in the altar.<ref name="Kleiner_23">{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=23}}</ref> While some altars contained remnants of the deceased, most Roman funerary altars had no practical function and only were erected to memorialize the dead.<ref name="Kleiner_23"/>
===Funerary altars versus votive altars===
The practice of erecting Roman funerary altars is linked to the tradition of constructing votive altars to honor the gods. Due to the acceptance that altars act as a symbol of reverence, it is believed that funerary altars were used to heroicize the deceased.<ref>{{harvp|Coulton|2005|p=128}}</ref> Funerary altars differed from votive altars that honored the gods, because they were not recipients of blood [[sacrifice]]s. Grave altars of heroes were connected with ritual sacrifices, but altars of regular Roman citizens were not. This practical difference is determined because Roman funerary altars do not have sacrificial pans or braziers.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=21}}</ref> By having a similar appearance to votive altars, the symbolism of the reverence of a sacrifice was implied, therefore conveying proper respect to the dead.<ref name="Coulton_129">{{harvp|Coulton|2005|p=129}}</ref> While having different meanings, the two types of altars were similarly constructed, both aboveground and round or rectangular in shape.<ref>{{harvp|Coulton|2005|p=145}}</ref>
===Locations===
Funerary altars of more wealthy Roman citizens were often found on the interior of more elaborate tombs.<ref name="Toynbee_266"/> Altars erected by the middle class were also set up in or outside of monumental tombs, but also in funerary precincts that lined the roads leading out of the city of Rome.<ref name="Kleiner_547">{{harvp|Kleiner|1987b|p=547}}</ref> The altars that were part of tomb complexes were set up on family plots or on building plots bought by spectators, who then sold them to individual owners.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=24}}</ref> Tombs and altars had a close connection in the mind of a Roman, evidenced by the Latin inscriptions where tombs are described as if they were altars.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=27}}</ref>
===Importance of epitaph===
[[Epitaph]]s on funerary altars provide much information about the deceased, most often including their name and their filiation or tribe.<ref name="Kleiner_547"/> Less often, the age and profession of the deceased was included in the epitaph.<ref name="Kleiner_45">{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=45}}</ref> A typical epitaph on a Roman funerary altar opens with a dedication to the [[manes]], or the spirit of the dead, and closes with a word of praise for the honoree.<ref name="Kleiner_45"/> These epitaphs, along with the pictorial attributes of the altars, allow historians to discern a lot of important information about ancient [[Roman funerary practices]] and monuments. Gathered from the funerary altars, it can be established that the majority of the altars were erected by a homogeneous group of middle-class citizens.<ref name="Kleiner_45"/>
===Dedicants and honorees=== [[File:Roman funerary altar for a boy, end of 1st century AD - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC09770.JPG|thumb|left|Roman funerary altar for a boy, end of 1st century AD - Royal Ontario Museum]] Epitaphs often emphasize the relationship between the deceased and dedicant, with most relationships being familial (husbands and wives, parents and children, etc.). Many altars also feature portraits of the deceased.<ref name="Kleiner_547"/> Extrapolated from the evidence of epitaphs and portraits on the altars, it can be concluded that [[freedman|freedmen]] and their descendants most frequently commissioned funerary altars in Rome—people who were teachers, architects, magistrates, writers, musicians and so on.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=28}}</ref>
The most common type of altar dedication is from parents to their deceased child. The epitaph often features the age of the child to further express grief at the death at such a young age. On the other hand, the age of a deceased person at an older age is rarely put on the epitaph.<ref name="Kleiner_45"/> Some other, less common, dedications are to parents from children, with the child most likely being a boy.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=50}}</ref> The second most common relationship of honorees is husband to wife or wife to husband.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=51}}</ref>
Outside of familial relationships, patrons sometimes dedicated altars to a slave or freedman and vice versa.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=54}}</ref> The relationship between dedicant and honoree of some altars that support this conclusion were actually husband and wife, because patrons sometimes married their freed slaves.<ref name="Kleiner_55">{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=55}}</ref> However, the relationship between patron and slave or freedman was not exclusionary to marriage, because sometimes these citizens had a personal relationship with a non-blood related person that they felt needed to be commemorated.<ref name="Kleiner_55"/>
It is important to note the prominence of women surrounding the discussion of Roman funerary altars, because it is rare for ancient Roman women to be so involved in any kind of monument of this time. Contrasting to most of the monuments that are surviving from Rome, women played a major part in funerary altars because many altars were erected in honor of or commissioned by a woman.<ref name="Kleiner_547"/> These women were honored as wives, mothers, and daughters, as well remembered for their professions. For example, these professional women were honored as [[priest]]esses, musicians, and poets. Sometimes the epitaph does not altar information about the profession of the honored woman, but details of the portrait (for example, the dress of the portrait) give clues to her vocation.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987b|p=550}}</ref> Many surviving altars honor women because, in ancient Rome, women tended to die young, due to childbirth and general hardships from marriage and overwork.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987b|p=548}}</ref> Roman women were honored often honored by their husbands, with some altars dedicated to the pair and with some just honoring the wife. Furthermore, some female children were honored in altars, commissioned by their grief-stricken parents.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987b|p=549}}</ref>
===Designs=== [[File:Frontons.png|thumb|Common varieties of pediments. Some of these forms were found on Roman funerary altars.]] Roman funerary altars had varied structures, with most reflecting the erection design of votive altars, which have flat tops.<ref>{{harvp|Coulton|2005|p=29}}</ref> For others, which most likely were designed to receive offerings, the tops of the altars were dished.<ref name="Coulton_129"/> Deeper cavities were created for ash urns to be placed inside.<ref name="Kleiner_23"/> Sizes of the altars could range from miniature examples to 2 meters tall.<ref name="Kleiner_547"/> Some carried busts or statues or portraits of the deceased.<ref name="Kleiner_547"/> The simplest and most common form of a funerary altar was a base with a [[pediment]], often featuring a portrait or epitaph, on top of the base.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=29}}</ref> They are almost all rectangular in shape and taller than they are wide. Plain or spiral columns usually frame the portrait or scene featured on the altar.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=31}}</ref>
Along with the typical portrait and epitaph, other motifs were inscribed in the altars. These motifs often had otherworldly or funerary meanings, which include [[laurel wreath]]s or fruit –swags.<ref>{{harvp|Toynbee|1996|p=265}}</ref> Mythological allusions in the design of the altar often aimed to liken the deceased to a divine being.<ref>{{harvp|Toynbee|1996|p=46}}</ref> Examples of these allusions include a young girl who is represented in the guise of [[Daphne]] transformed into a laurel tree or another girl who is portrayed as the goddess [[Diana (mythology)|Diana]]. Sometimes, tools that were characteristic of the deceased's profession were featured on the altar.<ref>{{harvp|Kleiner|1987a|p=46}}</ref> The design of the Roman funerary altars differs between each individual altar, but there are many overarching themes.
==Sarcophagi== {{Main|Ancient Roman sarcophagi}} ''"...a stone monument is an expression of permanence. It is no surprise, therefore, that the Roman obsession with personal immortality acquired its physical form in stone."''<ref>{{harvp|Elsner|Huskinson|Russell|2010|p=119}}</ref>
Sarcophagi were used in Roman funerary art beginning in the second century A.D., and continuing until the fourth century. A sarcophagus, which means "flesh-eater" in Greek, is a stone coffin used for inhumation burials.<ref name="Awan">{{harvp|Awan|2007}}</ref> Sarcophagi were commissioned not only for the elite of Roman society (mature male citizens),<ref name="Davies_47">{{harvp|Elsner|Huskinson|Davies|2010|p=47}}</ref> but also for children, entire families, and beloved wives and mothers. The most expensive sarcophagi were made from marble, but other stones, lead, and wood were used as well.<ref name="Awan"/> Along with the range in production material, there existed a variety of styles and shapes, depending on where the sarcophagus was produced and whom it was produced for.
===Before sarcophagi=== Inhumation burial practices and the use of sarcophagi were not always the favored Roman funerary custom. The [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]]s and Greeks used sarcophagi for centuries before the Romans finally adopted the practice in the second century.<ref name="Awan"/> Prior to that period, the dead were usually cremated and placed in marble ash chests or ash altars, or were simply commemorated with a grave altar that was not designed to hold cremated remains. Despite being the main funerary custom during the Roman Republic, ash chests and grave altars virtually disappeared from the market only a century after the advent of the sarcophagus.<ref>{{harvp|Elsner|Huskinson|Davies|2010|pp=21–22}}</ref>
It is often assumed that the popularity for sarcophagi began with the Roman aristocracy and gradually became more accepted by the lower classes.<ref name="Davies_47"/> However, in the past, the most expensive and ostentatious grave altars and ash chests were commissioned more frequently by wealthy freedmen and other members of the emerging middle class than by the Roman elite.<ref>{{harvp|Elsner|Huskinson|Davies|2010|p=45}}</ref> Due to this fact and the lack of inscriptions on early sarcophagi, there is not enough evidence to make a judgment on whether or not the fashion for sarcophagi began with a specific social class. Surviving evidence does indicate that a great majority of early sarcophagi were used for children. This suggests that the change in burial practice may not have simply stemmed from a change in fashion, but perhaps from altered burial attitudes. It is possible that the decision to begin inhuming bodies occurred because families believed that inhumation was a kinder, and less disturbing burial rite than cremation, thus necessitating a shift in burial monument.<ref name="Davies_47"/>
===Stylistic transition from altars and ash chests to sarcophagi=== Although grave altars and ash chests virtually disappeared from the market in the second century, aspects of their decoration endured in some stylistic elements of sarcophagi. The largest stylistic group of early sarcophagi in the second century is garland sarcophagi, a custom of decoration that was previously used on ash chests and grave altars. Though the premise of the decoration is the same, there are some differences. The garland supports are often human figures instead of the animal heads used previously. In addition, specific mythological scenes fill the field, rather than small birds or other minor scenes. The inscription panel on garland ash altars and chests is also missing on garland sarcophagi. When a sarcophagus did have an inscription, it seemed to be an extra addition and usually ran along the top edge of the chest or between the decorations.<ref>{{harvp|Elsner|Huskinson|Davies|2010|p=40}}</ref> The fact that early garland sarcophagi continued the tradition of grave altars with decorated garlands suggests that the customers and sculptors of sarcophagi had similar approaches to those who purchased and produced grave altars. Both monuments employed a similar collection of stylistic motifs with only subtle shifts in iconography.<ref>{{harvp|Elsner|Huskinson|Davies|2010|pp=44–45}}</ref>
===Metropolitan Roman, Attic, and Asiatic sarcophagus production centers=== [[File:Roman - Sarcophagus with the Triumph of Dionysus - Walters 2331.jpg|thumbnail|The Sarcophagus with the Triumph of Dionysus is a good example of a Metropolitan Roman style sarcophagus with its flat lid, three-sided decoration, and Dionysian scenes from Greek mythology.]] Sarcophagi production of the Ancient Roman Empire involved three main parties: the customer, the sculpting workshop that carved the monument, and the quarry-based workshop that supplied the materials. The distance between these parties was highly variable due to the extensive size of the Empire.<ref>{{harvp|Elsner|Huskinson|Russell|2010|pp=123–124}}</ref> Metropolitan Roman, Attic, and Asiatic were the three major regional types of sarcophagi that dominated trade throughout the Roman Empire.<ref name="Awan"/> Although they were divided into regions, the production of sarcophagi was not as simple as it might appear. For example, Attic workshops were close to [[Mount Pentelikon]], the source of their materials, but were usually very far from their client. The opposite was true for the workshops of Metropolitan Rome, who tended to import large, roughed out sarcophagi from distant quarries in order to complete their commissions. Depending on distance and customer request (some customers might choose to have elements of their sarcophagi left unfinished until a future date, introducing the possibility of further work after the main commission), sarcophagi were in many different stages of production during transport. As a result, it is difficult to develop a standardized model of production.<ref>{{harvp|Elsner|Huskinson|Russell|2010|pp=125–126}}</ref>
====Metropolitan Rome==== Rome was the primary production center in the western part of the empire. A Metropolitan Roman sarcophagus often took the shape of a low rectangular box with a flat lid. As the sarcophagus was usually placed in a niche or against a wall in a mausoleum, they were usually only decorated on the front and two shorter sides. Many were decorated with carvings of garlands and fruits and leaves, as well as narrative scenes from Greek mythology. Battle and hunting scenes, biographical events from the life of the deceased, portrait busts, the profession of the deceased and abstract designs were also popular.<ref name="Awan"/>
====Attic==== [[File:Roman - Garland Sarcophagus - Walters 2329.jpg|thumb|This is an example of an Asiatic garland sarcophagus, dated between 150 and 180 C.E. The sarcophagus is made from Dokimeion marble, so it was likely sculpted in Phrygia and then shipped to Rome. The sarcophagus has a gable-roof lid and exemplifies the garland tradition common on ash altars and chests. It also has several incomplete parts on its four sides, suggesting the work was interrupted or the sarcophagus was needed on short notice.]] Athens was the main production center for Attic style sarcophagi. These workshops mainly produced sarcophagi for export. They were rectangular in shape and were often decorated on all four sides, unlike the Metropolitan Roman style, with ornamental carvings along the bottom and upper edge of the monument. The lids were also different from the flat metropolitan Roman style and featured a pitched gable roof,<ref name="Awan"/> or a kline lid, which is carved in the style of couch cushions on which the form of the deceased reclines.<ref>{{harvp|Strong|Toynbee|1995|p=192}}</ref> The great majority of these sarcophagi also featured mythological subjects, especially the [[Trojan War]], Achilles, and battles with the [[Amazons]].<ref name="Awan"/>
====Asia Minor (Asiatic)==== The [[Dokimeion]] workshops in [[Phrygia]] specialized in architecturally formed large-scale Asiatic sarcophagi. Many featured a series of columns joined together by an entablature on all four sides with human figures in the area between the columns. The lids were often made in the gabled-roof design in order to complete the architectural-style sarcophagi so the coffin formed a sort of house or temple for the deceased. Other cities in Asia Minor produced sarcophagi of the garland tradition as well. In general, the sarcophagi were decorated on either three or four sides, depending on whether they were to be displayed on a pedestal in an open-air setting or against the walls inside tombs.<ref name="Awan"/>
===Myth and meaning on Ancient Roman sarcophagi=== A transition from the classical garland and seasonal reliefs with smaller mythological figures to a greater focus on full mythological scenes began with the break up of the classical style in the late second century towards the end of [[Marcus Aurelius]]' reign.<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|p=249}}</ref> This shift led to the development of popular themes and meanings portrayed through mythological scenes and allegories. The most popular mythological scenes on Roman sarcophagi functioned as aids to mourning, visions of life and happiness, and opportunities for self-portrayal for Roman citizens. Images of [[Meleager]], the host of the [[Calydonian Boar]] hunt, being mourned by Atalanta, as well as images of [[Achilles]] mourning [[Patroclus]] were very common on sarcophagi that acted as grieving aids. In both cases, the mythological scenes were akin to mourning practices of ordinary Roman citizens in an effort to reflect their grief and comfort them when they visited the tomb.<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|pp=62–66}}</ref> Playful images depicting [[Nereid]]s, Dionysiac triumphs, and love scenes of [[Dionysus]] and [[Ariadne]] were also commonly represented on sarcophagi.<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|pp=128–132}}</ref> It is possible that these scenes of happiness and love in the face of death and mourning encouraged the living to enjoy life while they could, and reflected the celebration and meals that the mourners would later enjoy in the tomb when they returned to visit the deceased.<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|pp=169–170}}</ref> The third century involved the return in popularity of self-representation on Roman sarcophagi. There were several different ways Roman citizens approached self-representation on sarcophagi. Some sarcophagi had actual representations of the face or full figure of the deceased. In other cases, mythological portraits were used to connect characteristics of the deceased with traits of the hero or heroine portrayed. For example, common mythological portraits of deceased women identified them with women of lauded traits in myth, such as the devoted [[Selene]] or loyal [[Alcestis]].<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|pp=199–206}}</ref> Scenes featuring the figures of Meleager and Achilles expressed bravery and were often produced on sarcophagi holding deceased men.<ref name="Awan"/> Biographical scenes that emphasize the true virtues of Roman citizens were also used to commemorate the deceased. Scholars argue that these biographical scenes as well as the comparisons to mythological characters suggest that self-portrayal on Roman sarcophagi did not exist to celebrate the traits of the deceased, but rather to emphasize favored Roman cultural values<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|p=199}}</ref> and demonstrate that the family of the deceased were educated members of the elite that could understand difficult mythological allegories.<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|p=30}}</ref>
===Third- and fourth-century sarcophagi=== The breakup of the classical style led to a period in which full mythological reliefs with an increase in the number of figures and an elongation of forms became more popular, as discussed above. The proportion of figures on the reliefs also became increasingly unbalanced, with the main figures taking up the greatest area with smaller figures crowded in the small pockets of empty space.<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|pp=249–250}}</ref> In the third century, another transition in theme and style of sarcophagi involved the return in popularity of representing mythological and non-mythological portraits of the deceased.<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|p=252}}</ref> Imagery of the four seasons also becomes popular during the third and fourth centuries. With the advent of Christianity in the third century, traditional motifs, like the seasons, remained, and images representing a belief in the afterlife appeared. The change in style brought by Christianity is perhaps most significant, as it signals a change in emphasis on images of retrospection, and introduced images of an afterlife.<ref>{{harvp|Zanker|Ewald|2012|pp=261–266}}</ref>
==Catacombs== {{Main|Catacombs of Rome}} The Roman catacombs are a series of underground cemeteries that were built in several major cities of the Roman Empire, beginning in the first and second centuries B.C.E. The tradition was later copied in several other cities around the world, though underground burial had been already common in many cultures before Christianity.<ref>{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=16}}</ref> The word "Catacomb" means a large, underground, Christian cemetery. Because of laws prohibiting burial within the city, the catacombs were constructed around the city along existing roads such as the [[Via Appia]], where San Callixtus and San Sebastiano can be found, two of the most significant catacombs.<ref name="Nicolai_9">{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=9}}</ref> The catacombs were often named for saints who were buried in them, according to tradition, though at the time of their burial, martyr cults had not yet achieved the popularity to grant them lavish tombs.<ref name="Bisconti_129">{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=129}}</ref> After 750 B.C.E., most of the remains of these martyrs were moved to the churches in the city above.<ref name="Nicolai_9"/> This was mainly undertaken by Pope Paul I, who decided to move the relics because of the neglected state of the catacombs.<ref>{{harvp|Osborne|1985|p=287}}</ref> The construction of catacombs started late in the first century and during this time they were used only for burial purposes and for funerary rites. The process of underground burial was abandoned, however, in the fifth century.<ref>{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=13}}</ref> A few catacombs remained open to be used as sites of pilgrimage because of their abundance of relics.<ref name="Bisconti_129"/>
Before Christians began to use catacombs for burial, they buried their dead in pagan burial areas.<ref>{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=14}}</ref> As a result of their community's economic and organizational growth, Christians were able to begin these exclusively Christian cemeteries.<ref>{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=15}}</ref> Members of the community created a "communal fund" which ensured that all members would be buried. Christians also insisted on inhumation and the catacombs allowed them to practice this in an organized and practical manner.
===Types of tombs=== [[File:DeRoss 001.jpg|thumbnail|Reconstruction of the Catacomb of Callistus]] The layout and architecture was designed to make very efficient use of the space<ref>{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=17}}</ref> and consisted of several levels with skylights that were positioned both to maximize lighting and to highlight certain elements of the decor.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=72}}</ref> There are several types of tomb in the catacombs, the simplest and most common of which is the ''[[Loculus (architecture)|loculus]]'' (pl. ''loculi''), a cavity in the wall closed off by marble or terra-cotta slabs. These are usually simple and organized very economically, arranged along the walls of the hallways in the catacombs. A ''mensa'' is a niche in the wall holding a sarcophagus while a ''cubiculus'' is more private, more monumental, and usually more decorated.<ref name="Nicolai_20">{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=20}}</ref> ''Cubicula'' use architectural structures, such as columns, pilasters, and arches, along with bold geometric shapes.<ref>{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=44}}</ref> Their size and elaborate decor indicate wealthier occupants. With the issuance of the [[Edict of Milan]], as Christians were less persecuted and gained more members of the upper class, the catacombs were greatly expanded and grew more monumental.<ref>{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=37}}</ref>
===Types of decor===
====Material of tombs==== Much of the material of the tombs was second-hand, some even still has pagan inscriptions on them from their previous use.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=100}}</ref> Marble was used often, partially because it reflected light and was light in color.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=85}}</ref> Clay bricks were the other common material that was used for structure and for decor. [[Roman concrete]] (volcanic rock, lime putty, and water — a combination which is incredibly resistant to wear) and a thin layer of stucco was spread over the walls of bare rock faces. This was not structural, only aesthetic, and was typically painted with frescoes.<ref>{{harvp|Sanchez-Moral|Luque|Cuezva|Soler|2005}}</ref>
====Inscriptions==== Tombs were usually marked with epitaphs, seals, Christian symbols, or prayers in the form of an inscription or painted in red lead, though often they were marked only with the name of the occupant.<ref name="Nicolai_20"/> Inscriptions in the Christian catacombs were usually in Latin or Greek, while in the Jewish catacombs they were written in either Greek or Hebrew.<ref>{{harvp|Mazzoleni|1999|p=152}}</ref> The majority of them are religiously neutral, while some are only graphic imitations of epitaphs (dashes and letters) that serve no meaning but to continue the funerary theme in an anonymous and efficient mass-production. Textual inscriptions also contained graphic elements and were matched in size and significance with decorative elements and elaborate punctuations marks.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=78}}</ref> Some Christians were too poor to afford inscriptions, but could inscribe their tomb with a short and somewhat sloppy [[Graffito (archaeology)|graffito]] while the mortar was still drying;<ref>{{harvp|Mazzoleni|1999|p=149}}</ref> Eventually, a code of equality was established ensuring that the tombs of poorer Christians would still be decorated, however minimally. The quality of writing on pagan tombstones is noticeably superior to that on Christian tombstones. This was probably due to the fact that Christians had less means, less access to specialized workers, and perhaps care more about the content of their inscriptions than their aesthetic.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=79}}</ref>
====Objects==== Objects were often set before, in, and in the mortar of tombs. These took the form of benches, stools, tables, and tableware and may have been used for rites such as the ''[[refrigerium]]'' (the funerary meal) which involved real food and drink.<ref name="Nicolai_45">{{harvp|Nicolai|1999|p=45}}</ref> Tables most likely held offerings of food while vases or other glass or ceramic containers held offerings of wine. Objects such as shells, dolls, buttons, jewelry, bells, and coins were added to the mortar of the ''loculi'' or left on shelves near the tomb. Some of these objects may have been encased in the tomb with the body and removed later.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=81}}</ref> Objects were much more common during and after the Constantinian period.<ref name="Nicolai_45"/>
====Frescoes==== The objects surrounding the tomb were reflected in the frescoes of banquets.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=110}}</ref> The tombs sometimes used mosaics, but frescoes were overwhelmingly more popular than mosaics. The walls were typically whitewashed and divided up into sections by red and green lines. This shows influence from Pompeian wall painting which tends toward extreme simplification of architectural imitation.<ref name="Bisconti_89">{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=89}}</ref>
''"The Severan period sees the definition of the wall surface as a chromatic unity, no longer intended as a space open towards an illusionary depth, but rather as a solid and substantial surface to be articulated with panels."''<ref name="Bisconti_89"/>
===Symbolism=== [[File:Good shepherd 02.jpg|thumbnail|left|Jesus as the [[Good Shepherd]]]] The organized and simple style of the frescoes manifests itself in two forms: an imitation of architecture, and clearly defined images. The images typically present one subject of religious importance and are combined together to tell a familiar (typically Christian) story. Floral motif<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=99}}</ref> and the Herculean labors (often used in pagan funerary monuments) along with other Hellenistic imagery are common and merge in their depictions of nature with Christian ideas of Eden.<ref>{{harvp|Berg|1994|p=219}}</ref> Similarly, seasons are a common theme and represent the journey through life from birth (spring) to death (winter), which goes with the occasional depictions of the Goddesses Ceres and Proserpina. There are many examples of pagan symbolism in the Christian catacombs, often used as parallels to Christian stories. The phoenix, a pagan symbol, is used to symbolize the Resurrection;<ref name="Bisconti_103">{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=103}}</ref> Hercules in the Garden of Hesperides symbolizes Adam, Eve, and the Serpent in the garden of Eden;<ref>{{harvp|Berg|1994|p=229}}</ref> the most famous symbol of the catacombs, the [[Good Shepherd]] is sometimes shown as Christ, but sometimes as the Greek figure Orpheus.<ref name="Bisconti_103"/> Most usage of pagan imagery is to emphasize paradisial aspects,<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=123}}</ref> though it may also indicate that either the patron or the artist was pagan.<ref>{{harvp|Berg|1994|p=220}}</ref> Other symbols include historical martyrs,<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=105}}</ref> funerary banquets,<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=109}}</ref> and symbols of the occupation of the deceased.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=115}}</ref> The most popular symbols are of the Jonah cycle, the Baptism of Christ, and the Good Shepherd and the fisherman.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=116}}</ref> The Good Shepherd was used as a wish for peaceful rest for the dead, but also acted as a guide to the dead who were represented by the sheep. Sometimes the Good Shepherd was depicted with the fisherman and the philosopher as the symbol of ultimate "peace on land and sea," though this is only briefly popular.<ref>{{harvp|Bisconti|1999|p=120}}</ref> These Old Testament scenes are also seen in Jewish catacombs.
==Tombstones and funerary inscriptions== [[File:Völkermarkt-St Stefan-Kirche-Römische Grabplatte.JPG|thumbnail|Roman epitaph from Church in Sankt Stefan in the community of Völkermarkt]] Culturally significant throughout the Empire, the erection and dedication of funerary tombstones was a common and accessible burial practice.<ref name="Oliver_1">{{harvp|Oliver|2000|p=1}}</ref> As in modern times, epitaphs were a means of publicly showcasing one's wealth, honor, and status in society.<ref name="Oliver_1"/> In this way, tombstones not only served to commemorate the dead, but also to reflect the sophistication of the Roman world.<ref name="Oliver_1"/> Both parties, therefore – the living and the dead – were venerated by and benefited from public burial.<ref>{{harvp|King|2000|p=118}}</ref> Though Roman tombstones varied in size, shape, and style, the epitaphs inscribed upon them were largely uniform.<ref name="King_130">{{harvp|King|2000|p=130}}</ref> Traditionally, these inscriptions included a prayer to the [[Manes]], the name and age of the deceased, and the name of the commemorator.<ref>{{harvp|Campbell|2015}}</ref> Some funerary inscriptions, though rare, included the year, month, day, and even hour of death.<ref>{{harvp|King|2000|p=139}}</ref> The design and layout of the epitaph itself would have often been left to the discretion of a hired stonemason.<ref name="King_130"/> In some cases, the stonemason would have even chosen the inscription, choosing a common phrase to complement the biographical information provided by the family of the deceased.<ref>{{harvp|King|2000|pp=130–131}}</ref> In death, one had the opportunity to idealize and romanticize their accomplishments; consequently, some funerary inscriptions can be misleading.<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=156}}</ref> Tombstones and epitaphs, therefore, should not be viewed as an accurate depiction of the Roman demographic.<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=157}}</ref>
===Freedmen and their children=== {{main|Married couple funerary reliefs}} In the Roman world, infant mortality was common and widespread throughout the Empire.<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2003|p=93}}</ref> Consequently, parents often remained emotionally detached from young children, so as to prevent or lessen future grief.<ref>{{harvp|King|2000|p=117}}</ref> Nonetheless, tombstones and epitaphs dedicated to infants were common among freedmen.<ref name="King_122">{{harvp|King|2000|p=122}}</ref> Of the surviving collection of Roman tombstones, roughly 75 percent were made by and for freedmen and slaves.<ref>{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|p=38}}</ref> Regardless of class, tombstones functioned as a symbol of rank and were chiefly popular among those of servile origin.<ref>{{harvp|King|2000|p=121}}</ref> As public displays, tombstones were a means of attaining social recognition and asserting one's rise from slavery.<ref>{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|pp=60–61}}</ref> Moreover, tombstones promoted the liberties of [[freeborn]] sons and daughters who, unlike their freed parents, were Roman citizens by birth.<ref>{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|p=61}}</ref> The child's [[tria nomina]], which served to show that the child was dignified and truly Roman, was typically inscribed upon the tombstone.<ref name="King_122"/> Infants additionally had one or two [[epithet]]s inscribed upon the stone that emphasized the moral aspects of the child's life.<ref>{{harvp|King|2000|pp=140–141}}</ref> These epithets served to express the fact that even young children were governed by [[Roman virtues]].<ref>{{harvp|King|2000|p=141}}</ref>
===Social elite=== [[File:Tombstones of Rome horsemen in Germany.jpg|thumbnail|Tombstones of Roman horsemen]] Members of the ruling class became interested in erecting funerary monuments during the Augustan-Tiberian period.<ref>{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|p=45}}</ref> Yet, by and large, this interest was brief. Whereas freedmen were often compelled to display their success and social mobility through the erection of public monuments, the elite felt little need for an open demonstration of this kind.<ref name="Mouritsen_47">{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|p=47}}</ref> Archeological findings in [[Pompeii]] suggest that tombs and monuments erected by freedmen increased at the very moment when those erected by the elite began to decrease.<ref name="Mouritsen_50">{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|p=50}}</ref> This change in custom signifies a restoration of pre-Augustan minimalism and austerity among the aristocracy in Rome.<ref name="Mouritsen_50"/> Self-remembrance among the social elite became uncommon during this time.<ref>{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|p=46}}</ref> Nonetheless governed by a strong sense of duty and religious piety, however, ancient Romans chose to celebrate the dead privately.<ref>{{harvp|King|2000|p=120}}</ref> With this change, noble or aristocratic families took to commemorating the deceased by adding inscriptions or simple headstones to existing burial sites.<ref name="Mouritsen_51">{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|p=51}}</ref> These sites, which were often located on the family's country estate, offered privacy to a grieving household.<ref name="Mouritsen_51"/> Unlike freedmen, the Roman elite rarely used tombstones or other funerary monuments as indicators of social status.<ref>{{harvp|Mouritsen|2005|p=43}}</ref> The size and style of one's [[cippi]], for example, was largely a personal choice and not something influenced by the need to fulfill greater social obligations.<ref name="Mouritsen_47"/>
===Soldiers=== {{main|Roman military tombstones}} [[File:The Cenotaph of Drusus (Drususstein), an empty tomb raised by Roman troops in 9 AD in honour of the deceased general Drusus, Mogontiacum (Mainz) (9739245693).jpg|thumb|upright|The Cenotaph of Drusus ([[Drususstein]]), an empty tomb raised by Roman troops in 9 AD to commemorate the deceased general Drusus]] In a military context, burial sites served to honor fallen soldiers as well as to mark newly sequestered Roman territory, such as [[Mainz]].<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=160}}</ref> The most common funerary monument for Roman soldiers was that of the [[stelae]] – a humble, unadorned piece of stone, cut into the shape of a rectangle.<ref name="Hope_163">{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=163}}</ref> The name, rank, and unit of the deceased would be inscribed upon the stone, as well as his age and his years of service in the [[Roman army]].<ref name="Hope_163"/> The name of the commemorator, usually an heir or close family member, could be inscribed near the bottom of the stelae if desired.<ref name="Hope_163"/> Uniform in nature, the consistent style of these tombstones reflected the orderly, systematic nature of the army itself.<ref name="Hope_163"/> Each tombstone stood as a testament to the strength and persistence of the Roman army as well as the individual soldiers.<ref name="Hope_87">{{harvp|Hope|2003|p=87}}</ref> In some unique cases, military tombstones were adorned with sculpture.<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=165}}</ref> These types of headstones typically belonged to members of the [[Auxilia|auxiliary units]] rather than [[legionary]] units.<ref name="Hope_167">{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=167}}</ref> The chief difference between the two units was citizenship.<ref name="Hope_167"/> Whereas legionary soldiers were citizens of Rome, auxiliary soldiers came from provinces in the Empire. Auxiliary soldiers had the opportunity to obtain [[Roman citizenship]] only after their discharge.<ref name="Hope_167"/> Tombstones served to distinguish Romans from non-romans, and to enforce the social-hierarchy that existed within military legions.<ref name="Hope_161">{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=161}}</ref> For men who died in battle, the erection of ornate tombstones was a final attempt at Romanization.<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=180}}</ref> Reliefs on auxiliary tombstones often depict men on horseback, denoting the courage and heroism of the auxiliary's [[cavalrymen]].<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2000|p=171}}</ref> Though expensive, tombstones were likely within the means of the common soldier.<ref name="Hope_161"/> Unlike most lower class citizens in ancient Rome, soldiers received a regular income.<ref name="Hope_161"/> Moreover, some historians suggest the creation of a burial club, a group organized to collect regular monetary contributions from the legions.<ref name="Hope_161"/> The proceeds served to subsidize the cost of burial for fallen soldiers.<ref name="Hope_161"/> Countless soldiers died in times of Roman war. Tombstones, therefore, were a way to identify and honor one's military service and personal achievement on the battlefield.<ref name="Hope_85">{{harvp|Hope|2003|p=85}}</ref> These tombstones did not commemorate soldiers who died in combat, but rather soldiers who died during times of peace when generals and comrades were at ease to hold proper burials.<ref name="Hope_85"/> Soldiers who died in battle were disrobed, cremated, and buried in mass graves near camp.<ref name="Hope_87"/> In some cases, heirs or other family members commissioned the construction of [[cenotaph]]s for lost soldiers - funerary monuments that commemorated the dead as if the body had been found and returned home.<ref>{{harvp|Hope|2003|p=89}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Sabina Guzzanti | image = Sabina Guzzanti.jpg | caption = Sabina Guzzanti in 2008 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|7|25|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Rome]], [[Italy]] | othername = | occupation = Satirist, Actress, Writer, Director, Producer | yearsactive = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = [[Paolo Guzzanti]] (father) | website = http://www.sabinaguzzanti.it/ | awards = '''[[European Film Awards|European Film Awards - Best Documentary Award]]'''
2005 ''[[Viva Zapatero!]]'' (Nominated)
'''[[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance Film Festival - Grand Jury Prize]]'''
2006 ''[[Viva Zapatero!]]'' (Nominated) }} '''Sabina Guzzanti''' (born 25 July 1963) is an Italian [[satire|satirist]], [[actress]], writer and producer whose work is devoted to examining social and political life in Italy. ==Early life== Born in [[Rome]] as the eldest daughter of celebrated Italian [[political commentator]] and journalist [[Paolo Guzzanti]] (former senator of [[Forza Italia]], incumbent deputy and deputy secretary for [[Italian Liberal Party (2004)|Italian liberal party]]), she graduated from the [[Accademia Nazionale di Arte Drammatica Silvio D'Amico|Academy of Dramatic Arts of Rome]].[http://biografie.leonardo.it/biografia.htm?BioID=225&biografia=Sabina+Guzzanti Biography] on Leonardo.it Her first appearances on stage were at the side of her brother [[Corrado Guzzanti|Corrado]], a skilled comedian known for parody and imitation. ==Career== Guzzanti's career began when she took part in a series of successful television comedy formats such as ''Proffimamente... non stop'' (directed by [[Enzo Trapani]]), ''L'araba fenice'' (directed by [[Antonio Ricci (producer)|Antonio Ricci]]), ''La TV delle ragazze'' and ''Scusate l'interruzione'';[http://www.repubblica.it/trovacinema/scheda_personaggio.jsp?long=true&idContent=155096 Profile] on [[La Repubblica]]'s website - Cinema section. her imitations of the famous Italian porn star [[Moana Pozzi]] gave her popularity, and the Italian film director [[Giuseppe Bertolucci]] recruited her to star in his film ''I Cammelli''. Her career in this period was at its apex, as she starred in several films, toured Italian theatres with her own comedy shows (such as ''Con fervido zelo'' in 1991, and ''Non io: Sabina e le altre'' in 1994), and even held her one-woman show ''La posta del cuore''. Her first attempt at directing is the 1998 short ''Donna selvaggia''. In November 2003 Sabina Guzzanti wrote, directed and was featured in the first and only installment of ''[[Raiot]]'', a late-night TV political satire show broadcast on [[Rai Tre]]. After lampooning Italian Prime Minister Berlusconi, she was sued by [[Silvio Berlusconi]]'s [[Mediaset]] lawyers (notably [[Cesare Previti]]'s law firm) for "lies and insinuation" and the show was pulled amid controversy; in the suing document Previti defined satire as "that thing which tends to minimize and to make a politician likeable, to diminish the social tensions" ("''quella cosa che tende a sdrammatizzare e a rendere simpatico un politico, a diminuire le tensioni sociali''"[http://www.disinformazione.it/intervistasabina.htm Interview with Sabina Guzzanti], excerpt from an article of [[L'Unità]]) as the basis to accuse the show of not being satirical but a direct political attack. As a form of protest, the second instalment was recorded live in the Auditorium of Rome and broadcast by independent television networks; during the event among others [[Dario Fo]], [[Beppe Grillo]] and [[Daniele Luttazzi]] gave her their support.[http://www.kataweb.it/speciali/guzzanti_auditorium/index.html Kataweb | Speciali | Raiot all'Auditorium] After that Sabina Guzzanti announced that the only official instalment of Raiot had completely vanished from the [[RAI]]'s archives. As a form of protest against the censorship imposed on ''RaiOt'', Sabina Guzzanti shot her side of the story in the film ''[[Viva Zapatero!|Viva Zapatero]]'' (2005) in which she shows and condemns the lack of freedom of expression in Italy.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/jul/21/worldcinema.documentary|title=Viva Zapatero!|last=Bradshaw|first=Peter|date=2006-07-21|website=the Guardian|access-date=2018-01-23}} The premier of ''Viva Zapatero!'' is in [[Venice Film Festival]] and there’s a great success.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2005/film/markets-festivals/viva-zapatero-1200521579/|title=Viva Zapatero!|last=Weissberg|first=Jay|date=2005-09-26|work=Variety|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}} ''Viva Zapatero!'' is invited in many others International Film Festival: Tribeca Film Festival, Sundance Film Festival and San Sebastian.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cinemaitaliano.info/film/00210/festival/viva-zapatero.html|title=Festival e premi: Viva Zapatero! (2005) - CinemaItaliano.info|website=su CinemaItaliano.info|access-date=2018-01-23}} At the end of 2005 she was once again allowed on television to feature in the last installment of [[Adriano Celentano]]'s show ''Rockpolitik'', but the producers "forbade" her to speak about [[Silvio Berlusconi]].[http://www.repubblica.it/2005/k/sezioni/spettacoli_e_cultura/cele2/guzz/guzz.html Silvio? Non gradivano, ho trattato sulle battute], interview with Gino Castaldo for [[La Repubblica]] After the victory of [[L'Unione]] in the [[Italian general election, 2006|2006 elections]] and the progressive fading of Berlusconi's influence on the RAI, she declared she still wouldn't return to work at the RAI unless serious reforms were launched to make the company's management independent from the politicians.[http://www.corriere.it/Primo_Piano/Spettacoli/2006/05_Maggio/29/conti.shtml La Guzzanti: non tornerò in una Rai lottizzata dall’Unione], interview with Paolo Conti for [[Corriere della Sera]] In 2007 she direct her second movie, ''[[Sympathy for the Lobster]] (Le Ragioni dell’Aragosta),'' a comedy which featured the comedians from ''Avanzi'', a popular political satire show much in vogue in the early nineties. In July 2008, in front of thousands of cheering onlookers at Piazza Navona, Rome, Guzzanti made hate speech remarks about the Pope, saying that he would be dead in 20 years, and would end up in [[Hell]] as punishment for the Church's treatment of homosexuals, saying that he would soon be "tormented by great big demons - and very active (sexual) ones". Although threatened with punishments of up to five years in prison for these comments, she was not prosecuted.Phil Stewart. [http://in.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idINIndia-35547620080918 Comic escapes prosecution for insulting pope], [[Reuters]], Sept. 19, 2008 After these events Guzzanti explaines her side of the story in a theatrical drama ''[[Vilipendio!]].''{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/SoleOnLine4/Tempo%20libero%20e%20Cultura/2009/04/Vilipendio-sabrina-guzzanti.shtml?uuid=1834c4d4-25ba-11de-9461-d9514a44e445&DocRulesView=Libero|title=Vilipendio Tour, satira in musica con Sabina Guzzanti - Il Sole 24 ORE|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ilsole24ore.com|access-date=2018-01-23}} In 2010 her third featured film, ''Draquila. Italy Trembles ([[Draquila – L'Italia che trema|Draquila]])'', is out of competition at [[Cannes Film Festival]].{{Cite web|url=http://www1.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/film-reviews/draquila-italy-trembles-film-review-1004089880.story|title=Draquila: Italy Trembles -- Film Review|website=www1.hollywoodreporter.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-23}} It’s a report of the events tied to the earthquake in L’Aquila, and an intense and disturbing story about the effects of autocracy. In 2011 Guzzanti directs ''Franca la Prima'', her personal homage to one of the most important actress in Italy, Franca Valeri.{{Cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.it/show/speciale-roma-2011/2011/10/31/festival-di-roma-sabina-guzzanti-franca-valeri-documentario|title=Roma s'inchina a Franca Valeri|website=www.vanityfair.it|access-date=2018-01-23}} During the same year Sabina back to theatre with ''Sì, Sì, Sì….oh Sì!'', a funny voyage through Italy's most important personalities from both the social and political sphere.{{Cite web|url=http://teatro.persinsala.it/si-si-si-oh-si/3533|title=Sì, sì, sì… oh, sì! – Persinsala Teatro|website=teatro.persinsala.it|language=it-IT|access-date=2018-01-23}} In March 2012 Guzzanti come back to TV with a new show, ''Un due tre…Stella!'' on [[La7]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.corriere.it/spettacoli/12_marzo_12/guzzanti-torna-piccolo-schermo_fb498a4e-6c56-11e1-bd93-2c78bee53b56.shtml|title="Un, due, tre stella": Sabina Guzzanti torna in tv|last=Online|first=Redazione|work=Corriere della Sera|access-date=2018-01-23|language=it-IT}} In 2014, her last featured film, ''[[The State-Mafia Pact|The State Mafia Pact]]'' (''La Trattativa''), is screened at the 71st [[Venice Film Festival]]. It's an accurate reconstruction of one of the most dark periods of Italian history: the pact between State and Mafia during the 90s and its effect on democracy.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/festivals/film-review-the-state-mafia-pact-1201306218/|title=Film Review: ‘The State-Mafia Pact’|last=Weissberg|first=Jay|date=2014-09-16|work=Variety|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}} In summer 2015 Guzzanti stars a new project, a web news satire called ''TG Porco'' which is financed by a crowdfunding.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2015/11/17/sabina-guzzanti-tgporco-se-vi-e-piaciuto-aiutateci-a-produrlo-la-campagna-di-crowdfunding/440477/|title=Sabina Guzzanti: "TgPorco? Se vi è piaciuto aiutateci a produrlo". La campagna di crowdfunding - Il Fatto Quotidiano|date=2015-11-17|work=Il Fatto Quotidiano|access-date=2018-01-23|language=it-IT}} In the same year she backs to theatre again with her new show, ''Come Ne Venimmo Fuori. Proiezioni dal Futuro'' which is a satiric monologue, an hilarious and punctual reflection on the post-capitalist and neo-liberal policies.{{Cite news|url=http://www.repubblica.it/spettacoli/teatro-danza/2015/10/14/news/sabina_guzzanti_sul_palco_per_dirvi_dal_futuro_quanto_eravamo_feroci_nel_2015_-125055518/|title=Sabina Guzzanti: "Sul palco per dirvi dal futuro quanto eravamo feroci nel 2015"|date=2015-10-14|work=Spettacoli - La Repubblica|access-date=2018-01-23|language=it-IT}} Since 1987, Sabina Guzzanti has practiced [[Nichiren Buddhism]] as a member of the global Buddhist association [[Soka Gakkai International]].[http://www.sgi-italia.org/riviste/bs/InternaTesto.php?A=1616&R=1&C=122 Article on Buddismo e Società] ==Criticism== Sabina Guzzanti is accused by various actors, politicians and writers of "aggression" against certain figures, mainly [[Silvio Berlusconi]] and his supporters. She has also derided the [[cancer]] of the journalist [[Oriana Fallaci]],[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dPoAeLAaMF0&feature=player_embedded Sabina Guzzanti deride the Oriana Fallaci's cancer - YouTube][http://www.qelsi.it/2011/come-la-guzzanti-derideva-il-cancro-di-oriana-fallaci/ Come la Guzzanti derideva il cancro di Oriana Fallaci], Quelsi Quotidiano, 12 August 2011 when during Fallaci's parody, a man shouted " May you as well get a cancer" (''Che ti venga un cancro''), and Guzzanti reply "I also already have it; and may it come to your mother too " (''Ce l'ho già e venisse anche alla tua mamma''). She also insulted [[Pope Benedict XVI]] and former Minister of Equal Opportunity [[Mara Carfagna]], who was accused by Guzzanti of [[fellating]] [[Silvio Berlusconi]], as reported by Carfagna herself.[http://www.ilmessaggero.it/articolo.php?id=32531&sez=HOME_INITALIA Sabina Guzzanti, la Carfagna chiede un milione di danni. L'attrice: «Bella donna ma che tariffe»], Il Messaggero, 9 October 2008[http://corrieredelmezzogiorno.corriere.it/salerno/notizie/politica/2012/9-ottobre-2012/sabina-guzzanti-diffamo-mara-carfagnaattrice-costretta-pagare-40mila-euro--2112173419149.shtml Sabina Guzzanti diffamò Mara Carfagna L'attrice costretta a pagare 40mila euro], il Corriere del Mezogiorno, 9 October 2012 After the scandal of the alleged "Madoff of Parioli," Sabina Guzzanti admitted to having given money to investors, as well. Aware of having been a victim of a scam, she said that she "felt like an idiot", claiming to have put in 150,000 €. Such revelation sparked another series of controversies, since during her speeches and her shows, she had always declared her opposition to this kind of practice, deemed typical of [[tax evader]]s. Guzzanti would have received - had everything gone as promised - earnings on her investments abroad, then exempt from taxation, within Italy itself.[http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/i-rivoluzionari-adessocadono-sulla-pensione.html I rivoluzionari adessocadono sulla pensione], Il Giornale, 1 February 2012 ==Works== [[Image:Sabina Guzzanti-Venezia-aragosta.jpg|thumb|250px|At the 64th [[Venice Film Festival]]]] ===Films=== *''[[La trattativa]]'', 2014 *''[[Draquila - L'Italia che trema]]'', script by Sabina Guzzanti, 2010 *''[[Le ragioni dell'aragosta]]'', directed and written by Sabina Guzzanti, 2007 *''[[Viva Zapatero!]]'', directed by Sabina Guzzanti, script by Sabina Guzzanti, 2005 *''[[Bimba - È clonata una stella|Bimba]]'', directed by Sabina Guzzanti, script by Sabina Guzzanti, 2001 *''Troppo sole'', directed by [[Giuseppe Bertolucci]], 1994 *''La cattedra'', directed by [[Michele Sordillo]], 1991 *''[[I ragazzi di via Panisperna]]'', directed by [[Gianni Amelio]], 1989 *''Night club'', directed by [[Sergio Corbucci]], 1989 *''[[The Camels]]'', directed by Giuseppe Bertolucci, 1988 ===Books=== *''Reperto RaiOt.'', published by BUR Biblioteca Universale Rizzoli, 2005 *''Viva Zapatero!'', published by BUR Biblioteca Universale Rizzoli, 2005 *''Il diario di Sabna Guzz'', published by Einaudi, 2003 *''Mi consenta una riflessione (anche se non è il mio ramo)'', published by Baldini Castoldi Dalai, 2002 ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons}} *{{IMDb name|0350127}} *[http://www.sabinaguzzanti.it/ Website in Italian] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060502091132/http://europa.eu.int/comm/avservices/audio/audio_thematic_en.cfm?th=Culture Press Conference] *[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/europe/story/0,,1091422,00.html The observer: No political satire please... we're Italian] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Guzzanti, Sabina}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Actresses from Rome]] [[Category:Italian actresses]] [[Category:Italian comedians]] [[Category:Freedom of expression]] [[Category:Italian satirists]] [[Category:Members of Sōka Gakkai]] [[Category:Italian Buddhists]] [[Category:Accademia Nazionale di Arte Drammatica Silvio D'Amico alumni]] [[Category:20th-century Italian actresses]] [[Category:21st-century Italian actresses]] [[Category:Italian film directors]] [[Category:Italian women film directors]] [[Category:Italian screenwriters]] [[Category:Women screenwriters]] [[Category:Italian documentary filmmakers]] [[Category:Italian film producers]] [[Category:Women film producers]] [[Category:Nichiren Buddhists]] [[Category:Former Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Women satirists]]
